subject: Fashion
title: Medieval Sumptuary Laws
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Medieval Sumptuary Laws.

hook.text: In 1363, English law banned peasants from wearing fur. Looking rich was literally illegal.

buildup.text: Sumptuary laws dictated exactly who could wear whatâ€”fabric, color, and trim matched to class.

discovery.text: Only royals could wear ermine. Merchants couldn't touch silk. Servants got plain wool.

twist.text: The laws kept failing. Rising merchants bought banned fabrics anyway and paid the fines gladly.

climax.text: Sumptuary laws revealed a deep fear: if anyone could dress like a noble, rank meant nothing.

punchline.text: When fashion crosses class lines, power gets nervous.

quiz.question: Why were medieval sumptuary laws frequently ineffective?
options: Wealthy merchants happily paid fines to wear banned fabrics
The laws only applied to women
